entry.title: Electrochemical Carbon Capture and Conversion: Recent Advances in Catalyst Design
entry.summary: The electrochemical reduction of CO2 to value-added chemicals represents a promising approach to carbon capture and utilization. In this review, we discuss recent advances in the design of heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 electroreduction, with particular emphasis on selectivity toward formate and formic acid production. We highlight the role of surface morphology, defect engineering, and bimetallic systems in tuning catalytic activity. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have provided critical insights into reaction intermediates and rate-limiting steps, guiding experimental efforts. Machine learning approaches have further accelerated catalyst discovery by enabling high-throughput screening of compositional and structural parameter spaces. Challenges including long-term stability, membrane design, and technoeconomic viability are discussed in the context of scaling these systems toward industrial deployment.

entry.title: Bayesian Optimization of Indium-Based Catalysts for CO2-to-Formate Electroreduction
entry.summary: We present a Bayesian optimization framework for accelerating the discovery of high-performance indium-based catalysts for the selective electroreduction of CO2 to formate. Starting from a design space of 240 candidate compositions, our Gaussian process surrogate model guided experimental synthesis and testing across three iterative campaigns. After 47 experiments, we identified an In-Sn alloy composition exhibiting a Faradaic efficiency of 94.2% and a partial current density of 312 mA/cm2 at -1.1 V vs RHE, representing state-of-the-art performance at this potential window. Feature importance analysis revealed that Sn content and annealing temperature were the dominant drivers of selectivity. This work demonstrates the practical utility of closed-loop ML-guided synthesis for electrocatalyst development, with implications for scalable direct air capture systems.
